bestBHT.bht: In this context, we see Jesus engaging in synagogue teaching, emphasizing his own presence as a teacher. His teachings were met with admiration and praise from all who heard him. He was the wonder teacher of his time, surpassing even the rabbis in his wisdom and ability to captivate an audience. The synagogues provided an open door for Jesus before the hostility of the Pharisees arose. People were astonished by his doctrine and gracious words, glorifying both him and God for the mighty works done through him.

Henry Alford: This verse, containing a general undefined notice of our Lord’s synagogue teaching, quite takes from what follows any chronological character.
We find throughout the early part of this Gospel the same fragmentary stamp.

Compare 'on the sabbath days,' ver. 31— 'as the people pressed on him,' ch. v. 1— 'when he was in a certain city,' ch. v. 12— 'on a certain day,' ch. v. 17; viii. 22— 'on another sabbath,' ch. vi. 6— 'in these days,' ch. vi. 12, &c. &c.
Albert Barnes: Glorified of all - Praised by all; or, all were pleased with his instructions, and admired his wisdom.
Marvin Vincent: He taught [αυτος εδιδασκεν] . Lit., "he himself taught," verifying the favorable reports about himself in person. The imperfect tense denotes a course of teaching.
John Calvin: From the very commencement, a divine power shone in Christ."
Compelled even those, who cherished a malignant spirit of contradiction, to join in admiring him."
Philip Schaff: Such teaching is alluded to in Luke 4:16.
The second miracle at Cana (the healing of the nobleman’s son; John 4:46-54) occurred during the period here referred to.
In their synagogues. Comp. Luke 4:16; Luke 4:23.
Archibald T. Robertson: He taught... it is not certain that he means to emphasize 'he himself' as distinct from the rumour about him." (Luke 4:15)
The synagogues were an open door to Jesus before the hostility of the Pharisees was aroused." (Luke 4:15)
He was the wonder teacher of his time. Even the rabbis had not yet learned how to ridicule and oppose Jesus." (Luke 4:15)
John Gill: And he taught in their synagogues... and Christ engaging here as a public teacher, was the reason of his fame being spread around the country.
Being glorified of all; that heard him: they were astonished at his doctrine; they wondered at his gracious words.
They praised him as a preacher; and glorified him, and God for him, because of the mighty works which were done by him.
John Wesley: So God usually gives strong cordials after strong temptations.
But neither their approbation continued long, nor the outward calm which he now enjoyed.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 4:15, we see a general notice of our Lord's synagogue teaching, which suggests that the following events are not necessarily in chronological order. Throughout the early part of this Gospel, we find fragments of Jesus' teachings at various locations and times. He taught in the synagogues, an open door for Him before the hostility of the Pharisees arose. People were amazed by His teachings, praising and glorifying Him. Even the rabbis hadn't learned how to oppose Him yet. This period of teaching and miraculous activities contributed to His growing fame. However, this outward calm and glory didn't last long, as the approval of some turned into opposition. But during this time, Jesus' divine power shone, causing admiration and wonder among those who heard Him speak.

In this passage, we see Jesus engaging as a public teacher in the synagogues. He taught with authority, and his teachings were met with admiration and astonishment. People praised and glorified him for his gracious words and the mighty works he performed. This period of teaching and miraculous acts contributed to his growing fame, even among those who initially held a spirit of contradiction. However, this outward calm and glory didn't last long, as opposition eventually arose. Jesus' divine power and captivating teachings drew people in, leaving them in awe of him.

In this verse, we witness the beginning of Jesus' teaching ministry in the synagogues. His teachings were marked by divine power, causing admiration and wonder among all who heard him. People praised and glorified him as a preacher, amazed by his doctrine and gracious words. The synagogues served as an open door for Jesus before the Pharisees' opposition arose. Jesus' ability to captivate an audience and perform mighty works made him a wonder teacher of his time, with even the rabbis yet to learn how to oppose him.

In this context, we see Jesus engaging in synagogue teaching, emphasizing his own presence as a teacher. His teachings were met with admiration and praise from all who heard him. He was the wonder teacher of his time, surpassing even the rabbis in his wisdom and ability to captivate an audience. The synagogues provided an open door for Jesus before the hostility of the Pharisees arose. People were astonished by his doctrine and gracious words, glorifying both him and God for the mighty works done through him.

In this scene, Jesus begins his synagogue teaching, with his personal presence emphasized. His captivating teachings garnered admiration and praise from those who heard him. He became the wonder teacher of his time, outshining the rabbis who had not yet learned to oppose him. The synagogues served as open doors for Jesus before the Pharisees' hostility arose. People were astonished by his doctrine and gracious words, glorifying him and God for the mighty works performed through him.
